newsitem.title: USA: Fund watcher sees Magellan hiking GE, Philip Morris.
newsitem.headline: Fund watcher sees Magellan hiking GE, Philip Morris.

text.p: Donald Dion, publisher of the Fidelity Independent Adviser newsletter, said in interviews Wednesday he expects Magellan fund manager Bob Stansky to hike holdings in General Electric and Philip Morris.
"Over the next few months, we believe that Stansky will be able to more aggressively pursue his favorite stocks from his days at Fidelity Growth Company," Dion said in a statement.

Since Stansky took over the nation's largest mutual fund in June, he has accummulated growth stocks such as GE, Philip Morris, Cisco Systems, Oracle and Federal National Mortgage Association, Dion noted.

"Fidelity seems to look at Philip Morris the way many of us look at Marlboros - dangerous, but worth the risk," Dion said, noting Fidelity owns 67 million shares of the tobacco industry leader or 8.15 percent of the total outstanding shares.
When Philip Morris shares dropped in March from $104.50 to $86.25, Fidelity bought 9.5 million shares of the stock over the following three months.
"We believe that Fidelity will be holding on to its Philip Morris position and if anything, adding even more shares to its collection," he said.

Michael DeMarco, who edits Dion's newsletter, said Stansky has been limited in his flexibility by redemptions in Magellan - the net assets have declined to $52 billion from $56 billion. Therefore, the top 10 stocks in the behemoth fund still consist of Caterpillar, General Motors, CSX, Exxon and other holdovers from former Magellan fund manager Jeff Vinik.
But as the redemptions have slowed, Dion said, Stansky "will turn Magellan around to the benefit of its many shareholders."
